revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1520|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1520'''.
==Events== *Scholars at [[Complutense University]], [[Alcalá de Henares]], under the direction of [[Diego López de Zúñiga (theologian)|Diego Lopez de Zúñiga]] complete the [[Complutensian Polyglot Bible]]. *[[Ulrich von Hutten]]'s satiric poem ''Aufwecker der teutschen Nation'' is published, his earliest work in German.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Magnusson, Magnus|title=Chambers Biographical Dictionary|location=Cambridge; Edinburgh|publisher=Cambridge University Press; W. & R. Chambers Ltd|edition=5th|year=1990|isbn=0-550-16040-X}}</ref>
==New books== ===Prose=== *''[[Hochstratus Ovans]]'' *[[Martin Luther]] **''[[To the Christian Nobility of the German Nation]]'' (''An den christlichen Adel deutscher Nation'') **''[[On the Babylonian Captivity of the Church]]'' (''De captivitate Babylonica ecclesiae praeludium'') **''[[On the Freedom of a Christian]]'' *[[Niccolò Machiavelli]] – ''[[Discourse on Reforming the Government of Florence]]'' (''Discorso sopra il riformare lo stato di Firenze'') *Shin Maha Thilawuntha – ''[[Yazawin Kyaw]]'' (Burmese), supplement
===Drama=== *[[John Heywood]] – ''[[Johan Johan The Husband]]'' *''Approximate year'' – [[Niccolò Machiavelli]]: ''[[Andria (Machiavelli)|Andria]]''
===Poetry=== {{main|1520 in poetry}} *[[Robert Copland]] – {{sic|hide=y|''L'enuoy of Robert Coplande''}} (published in London by [[Wynkyn de Worde]])<ref name=CHEPD>{{cite web|url=http://www-sul.stanford.edu/depts/hasrg/ats/engpo5-toc.html |work=Academic Text Service (ATS) |title=Chadwyck-Healey English Poetry Database – Tudor Poetry, 1500-1603 |publisher=Stanford University Library |accessdate=2009-09-08 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhECwytY?url=http://www-sul.stanford.edu/depts/hasrg/ats/engpo5-toc.html |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Terence]] (translated) – ''Terens in Englysh'' (published in Paris)<ref name=CHEPD/> *''Approximate year'' ** [[John Lydgate]] – ''Testament''<ref name=COCEL>{{cite book|editor=Cox, Michael|title=The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-860634-6}}</ref> ** ''Alexander the Great''<ref name=COCEL/> ** ''[[The Squire of Low Degree]]'' (written c.1500; published in London by Wynkyn de Worde)<ref name=COCEL/>
==Births== *''Unknown date'' – [[Natalis Comes]], Italian mythologist, poet and historian (died [[1582 in literature|1582]]) *''Approximate years'' **[[Hernando de Acuña]], Spanish poet (died [[1580 in literature|1580]]) **[[Giovanni Bona de Boliris]], Italian humanist, poet and writer, writing in Latin and Italian (died [[1572 in literature|1572]]) **[[Thomas Churchyard]], English author and poet (died [[1604 in literature|1604]]) **[[Pernette Du Guillet]], French poet (died [[1545 in literature|1545]]) **[[Jorge de Montemor]], Portuguese novelist and poet, writing in Spanish (died [[1561 in literature|1561]]) **[[Christophe Plantin]], French-born Dutch humanist and printer (died [[1589 in literature|1589]]) **[[Madeleine Des Roches]] (Madeleine Neveu), French author, poet and saloniste (died [[1587 in literature|1587]]) **[[Alexander Scott (16th-century poet)|Alexander Scott]], Scottish poet (died [[1582 in literature|1582/83]]) **[[Georg Thym]], German teacher, poet and writer (died [[1560 in literature|1560]])
==Deaths== *''Unknown date'' – [[William Dunbar]], Scottish poet (born [[1460 in literature|1459/60]])
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1520 In Literature}} [[Category:1520]] [[Category:1520 books]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1611|music}}
The year '''1611 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
== Events == *[[January 1]] – ''[[Oberon, the Faery Prince]]'', a [[masque]] written by [[Ben Jonson]] and designed by [[Inigo Jones]], is performed at [[Whitehall Palace]]; it features music by [[Alfonso Ferrabosco the younger]] and [[Robert Johnson (English composer)|Robert Johnson]]. *[[February 3]] – ''[[Love Freed from Ignorance and Folly]]'', another Jonson/Jones masque, is performed at Whitehall, with music by Ferrabosco.
== Publications == *[[Robert Ballard (lutenist)|Robert Ballard]] – a collection of arrangements for the lute. *[[William Byrd]] – ''Psalms, Songs, and Sonnets'' *[[Carlo Gesualdo]] **Sixth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a'' 5 **''[[Responsoria et alia ad Officium Hebdomadae Sanctae spectantia]]'', a 6 *[[Johannes Hieronymus Kapsberger]] – ''Libro primo d'intavolatura di lauto'' *''[[Parthenia (music)|Parthenia]]'', a collection of keyboard music by [[John Bull (composer)|John Bull]], [[William Byrd]], and [[Orlando Gibbons]]
==Popular music== * [[Thomas Ravenscroft]] – ''Melismata''
== Classical music == {{Empty section|date=July 2010}}
== Opera == *[[Giulio Cesare Monteverdi]] – ''Il rapimento di Proserpina'' <ref>{{cite web|title=Opera Composers: M|url=http://opera.stanford.edu/composers/M.html |website=OperaGlass}}</ref>
== Births == *[[June 22]] – [[Pablo Bruna]], blind organist and composer (died [[1679 in music|1679]])<ref>{{GroveOnline|title=Pablo Bruna|author=Almonte Howell|author2=Louis Jambou|access-date=November 18, 2006}}</ref> *December – [[Leonora Baroni]], singer, instrumentalist and composer (died 1670) *''date unknown'' – [[Thomas Brewer (composer)|Thomas Brewer]], composer who introduced the "glee"
== Deaths == *July – [[Simon Lohet]], organist and composer (born c. 1550) *[[August 20]] – [[Tomás Luis de Victoria]], composer (born c. 1548) *''date unknown'' **[[Livia d'Arco]], singer (born c. 1565) **[[Pierre-Francisque Caroubel]], violinist and composer (born [[1556 in music|1556]]) **[[Johannes Eccard]], composer and conductor (born 1553) **[[Gioseffo Guami]], organist, singer and composer (born c. 1540)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1611|Music]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Year nav topic5|1620|architecture}} {| class="infobox" |- style="background-color:#f3f3f3" | align="center" | [[1610s in architecture|1610s]] · '''1620s in architecture''' · [[1630s in architecture|1630s]] |- | align="center" | [[Architecture timeline]] |} __TOC__
==Buildings== [[File:I'timād-ud-Daulah, Agra.jpg|thumb|[[Tomb of I'timād-ud-Daulah]], Agra]] * 1619 – [[Børsen]] in [[Copenhagen]], Denmark designed by [[Lorenz van Steenwinckel|Lorentz]] and [[Hans van Steenwinckel the Younger]], is begun (completed 1640) * 1620 ** Work on [[Santa Maria delle Grazie Tower]] in [[Xgħajra]], [[Malta]] begins. ** Reconstruction of [[Frederiksborg Palace]], Denmark, is completed by [[Hans van Steenwinckel the Younger]] following the death of his brother [[Lorenz van Steenwinckel|Lorentz]]. ** [[Skaill House]] on [[Orkney]] is built. * 1616–1621 – Church of [[St-Gervais-et-St-Protais]], Paris, designed by [[Salomon de Brosse]], is built. * 1621 – Prince's Lodging at [[Newmarket, Suffolk]], England, designed by [[Inigo Jones]], completed. * 1622–1628 – The [[Tomb of I'timād-ud-Daulah]] in [[Agra]], India, is built. * 1622 – The [[Banqueting House, Whitehall]], [[London]], is opened with a performance of [[Ben Jonson]]'s ''[[The Masque of Augurs]]'' designed by the building's architect, [[Inigo Jones]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Banqueting House|url=http://www.roughguides.com/travel/europe/england/london/whitehall/banqueting-house.aspx|work=London Guide|publisher=[[Rough Guides]]|accessdate=2012-08-27}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> * 1623 – New [[:fr:Temple de Charenton-le-Pont|Temple de Charenton-le-Pont]], France, designed by [[Salomon de Brosse]] and [[Jean Thiriot]], is built. * 1624 – [[St John's College Old Library, Cambridge]], building is completed. * 1624–1626 – Façade of [[Santa Maria della Vittoria, Rome]], designed by [[Giovanni Battista Soria]], is built. * 1623–1627 – [[Queen's Chapel]] at [[St James's Palace]] in London, designed by [[Inigo Jones]], is built. * 1615–1625 – [[Luxembourg Palace]], Paris, designed by [[Salomon de Brosse]], is built. * c. 1625/26 – Coymans house, Keizersgracht, [[Amsterdam]], designed by [[Jacob van Campen]]. * 1626 – Rebuilding of [[Palsangjeon#Beopjusa Palsangjeon|Beopjusa Palsangjeon]] in Korea is completed. * 1627 ** [[Palazzo Barberini]] in [[Rome]] begun by [[Carlo Maderno]] and [[Francesco Borromini]] (completed [[1630s in architecture|1633]]). ** [[Muchalls Castle]] in [[Scotland]], reconstruction completed by Thomas [[Clan Burnett|Burnett of Leys]]. * 1628 – [[George Heriot's Hospital]] in [[Edinburgh]], Scotland. * 1629 – [[Simtokha Dzong]] (castle-monastery) in [[Bhutan]].
==Births== * 1620: November 2 ''(bapt.)'' – [[Roger Pratt (architect)|Roger Pratt]], English gentleman architect (died [[1684 in architecture|1684]]) * 1621 – [[Hugh May]], English architect (died 1684)
==Deaths== * 1620 – [[Bontadino de Bontadini]], Bolognese-born hydraulic engineer, architect, mathematician and woodcarver, murdered * 1626: December 9 – [[Salomon de Brosse]], French architect (born [[1571 in architecture|1571]]) * 1627: July 17 – [[Lieven de Key]], Dutch architect (born [[1560 in architecture|1560]]) * 1629: January 30 – [[Carlo Maderno]], Ticinese-born architect (born [[1556 in architecture|1556]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1620s architecture|*]] [[Category:1620s works|Architecture]]

{{Dynamic list}} {{Infobox | headerstyle = background-color:#ddd; | header1 = Years in stand-up comedy | data2 = {{Space separated entries | [[2014 in stand-up comedy|2014]] | [[2015 in stand-up comedy|2015]] | [[2016 in stand-up comedy|2016]] | '''2017''' | [[2018 in stand-up comedy|2018]] | [[2019 in stand-up comedy|2019]] }} }}
This is a timeline documenting events and facts about [[stand-up comedy]] in the year 2017.
== Events ==
* February 14: ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' publishes a ranked [[listicle]] entitled ''50 Best Stand-Up Comics of All Time''. [[Richard Pryor]] ranks first, considering artistic merit, technical proficiency, [[Comic timing|sense of timing]], quality of written material, delivery and degree of influence.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/lists/50-best-stand-up-comics-of-all-time-w464199 |title=50 Best Stand-Up Comics of All Time |website=Rolling Stone |first=Matthew |last=Love |date=February 14, 2017 |accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> * February 28: [[John Caparulo]] is assaulted by two women from the audience at [[The Comedy & Magic Club]] in Hermosa Beach, California, after making a phallic joke about [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rawstory.com/2017/03/trump-supporter-assaults-comedian-john-caparulo/ |title=VIDEO: Trump supporter assaults comedian John Caparulo in California club |website=Raw Story |first=Samantha |last=Karas |date=March 1, 2017 |accessdate=March 3, 2017}}</ref>
== Deaths ==
* April 6: [[Don Rickles]] dies of [[kidney failure]], at the age of 90, at his home in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/don-rickles-lightning-fast-launcher-of-comic-insults-dies-at-90/2017/04/06/d785d626-1af2-11e7-855e-4824bbb5d748_story.html |title=Don Rickles, lightning-fast launcher of comic insults, dies at 90 |website=The Washington Post |first=Matt |last=Schudel |date=April 6, 2017 |accessdate=April 7, 2017}}</ref> * April 12: [[Charlie Murphy]] dies at the age of 57 in New York, suffering from [[leukemia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/04/12/entertainment/charlie-murphy-dead/index.html |title=Charlie Murphy has died after a battle with leukemia |website=CNN |first=Chloe |last=Melas |date=April 13, 2017 |accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> * August 19: [[Dick Gregory]] dies of [[heart failure]] at the age of 84 in Washington.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-dick-gregory-20170819-story.html |title=Dick Gregory, who rose from poverty to become a groundbreaking comedian and civil rights activist, dies at 84 |last=McLellan |first=Dennis |date=August 19, 2017 |website=Los Angeles Times |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * August 20: [[Jerry Lewis]] dies of [[cardiovascular disease]], at the age of 91, at his home in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/people-news/jerry-lewis-dies-dead-nutty-professor-1202533899/ |title=Jerry Lewis, Comedy Legend, Dies at 91 |last1=Natale |first1=Richard |last2=Dagan |first2=Carmel |date=August 20, 2017 |website=Variety |access-date=December 25, 2017}}</ref> * September 19: [[Jake LaMotta]] dies of [[pneumonia]] at the age of 95 in Florida.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/sports/jake-lamotta-dead.html |title=Jake LaMotta, 'Raging Bull in and Out of the Ring, Dies at 95 |last=Goldstein |first=Richard |date=September 20, 2017 |website=The New York Times |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * October 6: [[Ralphie May]] dies of [[cardiac arrest]] at the age of 45 in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2017/10/ralphie-may-dies-at-45/ |title=Ralphie May Dies at 45 |last=Wright |first=Megh |date=October 6, 2017 |website=Splitsider |access-date=October 8, 2017}}</ref> * October 16: [[Sean Hughes (comedian)|Sean Hughes]] dies of cardiac arrest at the age of 51, while also suffering from [[cirrhosis]] of the liver.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global/2017/oct/19/remembering-sean-hughes-the-sadness-is-he-didnt-get-to-be-old-just-lonely |title=Remembering Sean Hughes: ‘The sadness is he didn’t get to be old, just lonely’ |last=Hann |first=Michael |date=October 19, 2017 |website=The Guardian |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref>
== Releases == {{Missing information|section|[[Comedy album|albums]], DVDs and half-hour [[Television special|specials]]|date=December 2017}} {{Refimprove section|date=December 2017}}
=== January ===
* January 3: [[Jen Kirkman]]'s one-hour special ''Just Keep Livin’?'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the [[Bowery Ballroom]] in New York.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/12/jen-kirkman-just-keep-livin-trailer-netflix-special-1201763297/ |title=‘Just Keep Livin’?’ Trailer: Comedian Jen Kirkman Returns For a Second Netflix Special |last=Murthi |first=Vikram |date=December 28, 2016 |website=IndieWire |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * January 5: [[Brian Posehn]]'s one-hour special ''Posehn 25x2'' is released on [[Seeso]].<ref name="Posehn">{{Cite web |url=http://brianposehn.com/site/2017/03/10/185-2/ |title=The new album from Brian Posehn POSEHN 25X2 Available Now! |author=Staff |date=March 10, 2017 |website=Brian Posehn |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Revolution Hall]] in Portland, Oregon.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theblacklistnyc.com/brianp |title=Posehn 25x2 |author=Staff |website=The Black List NYC |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * January 6th: [[Janeane Garofalo]] album version of her October 26 special ''If I May'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The album was recorded in San Francisco, California. * January 10: [[Jim Gaffigan]]'s one-hour special ''Cinco'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix">{{Cite web |url=http://fox2now.com/2016/12/16/everything-coming-and-going-on-netflix-in-january/ |title=Everything coming and going on Netflix in January |author=Tribune Media |date=December 16, 2016 |website=FOX2now.com |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Palace Theatre (Columbus, Ohio)|Palace Theatre]] in Columbus, Ohio.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 13: [[Kelly MacFarland]]'s album ''You Woke Up Today'' is released on [[iTunes]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] by Rooftop Comedy. The album was recorded at the [[ImprovBoston]] in Cambridge, Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theinterrobang.com/kelly-macfarland-holds-pajama-party-themed-album-release-event/ |title=Kelly MacFarland Holds Pajama Party Themed Album Release Event |website=The Interrobang |first=Amma |last=Marfo |date=January 19, 2017 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}}</ref> * January 13: Mo Mandel's album version of his November 2016 special ''Negative Reinforcement'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The album was recorded at the [[Gothic Theatre|Gothic Theater]] in Denver, Colorado. * January 17: [[Neal Brennan]]'s one-hour special ''3 Mics'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix" /> The special was filmed at the Belasco Theatre in Los Angeles.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 20: [[Dan Levy]]'s album version of his November 2016 special ''Lion'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * January 20: [[Jena Friedman]]'s album version of her October 2016 special ''American Cunt'' is released on [[iTunes]]. The album was recorded at [[The Slipper Room]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/albums/album-version-jena-friedmans-american-cnt-will-available-january/ |title=The album version of Jena Friedman’s ''American C*nt'' will be available this January |website=The Laugh Button |author=Mark Says Hi! |date=December 21, 2016 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}}</ref> * January 24: [[Cristela Alonzo]]'s one-hour special ''Lower Classy'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix" /> The special was filmed at the Empire Theatre in San Antonio.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 24: [[Gad Elmaleh]]'s one-hour special ''Gad Gone Wild'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix" /> The special was filmed at the L'Olympia in Montreal{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} and performed mainly in French.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/video/heres-first-look-gad-elmalehs-special-gad-gone-wild-coming-netflix/ |title=Here's your first look at Gad Elmaleh's special "Gad Gone Wild" coming to Netflix |author=Mark Says Hi! |date=January 11, 2017 |website=The Laugh Button |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * January 26: [[Adam Newman (comedian)|Adam Newman]]'s one-hour special ''Fuzzies'' is released on Seeso.<ref name="Newman">{{Cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2016/11/seeso-announces-2017-premiere-dates-for-new-and-returning-shows-and-standup-specials/ |title=Seeso Announces 2017 Premiere Dates for New and Returning Shows and Standup Specials |last=Wright |first=Megh |date=November 1, 2016 |website=Splitsider |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Georgia Theatre]] in Athens, Georgia.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 27: [[Aries Spears]]' album version of his November 2016 special ''Comedy Blueprint'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The special was filmed in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. * January 31: [[Bill Burr]]'s one-hour special ''Walk Your Way Out'' is released on Netflix.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/01/bill-burr-returns-with-new-stand-up-special-walk-y.html |title=Bill Burr to Return with New Netflix Stand-Up Special Walk Your Way Out |last=McNett |first=Jared |date=January 18, 2017 |website=Paste |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] in Nashville, Tennessee.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}}
=== February ===
* February 3: [[Joe DeRosa (comedian)|Joe DeRosa]]'s one-hour special ''You Let Me Down'' is released on [[Comedy Central]]. The special was filmed at The Masonic Lodge at [[Hollywood Forever Cemetery]] in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://press.cc.com/press-release/2017/01/27/press-joe-derosa-you-let-me-down-premieres-february-3-at-midnight-etpt |title=PRESS – Joe DeRosa You Let Me Down Premieres February 3 at Midnight ETPT |website=Comedy Central}}</ref> * February 3: [[Katie Goodman]]'s album ''Halfway Closer to Dead'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * February 10: [[Nick Cannon]]'s one-hour special ''Stand Up Don't Shoot!'' is released on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]. The special was filmed at the Ebony Repertory Theatre in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sho.com/titles/3438320/nick-cannon-stand-up-dont-shoot |title=Nick Cannon: Stand Up, Don't Shoot |website=Showtime}}</ref> * February 10: [[Joey Diaz|Joey Coco Diaz]]'s album version of his December 2016 special ''Sociably Unacceptable'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * February 14: [[Katherine Ryan]]'s one-hour special ''In Trouble'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/01/18/26657/netflix_signs_katherine_ryan |title=Netflix signs Katherine Ryan, Stand-up special out on Valentine's Day |website=Chortle}}</ref> * February 16: [[Nick Di Paolo]]'s one-hour special ''Inflammatory'' is released on [[Seeso]].<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=830607505243926528 |user=NickDiPaolo |title=My all new special “INFLAMMATORY” premieres on @SeesoTV 2/16! |author=Nick Di Paolo |date=February 12, 2017 |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the Suffolk Theater in Riverhead, New York.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * February 17: [[Andy Kindler]]'s album ''State of the Industry'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * February 16: [[Gina Yashere]]'s one-hour special ''Ticking Boxes'' is released on Seeso. The special was filmed at the [[O2 Brixton Academy]] in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ginayashere.com/ |title=Gina Yashere |website=Gina Yashere |accessdate=February 20, 2017}}</ref> * February 19: [[Roy Wood Jr.]]'s one-hour special ''Father Figure'' is released on Comedy Central. The special was filmed at the [[Center Stage Atlanta|Center Stage Theater]] in Atlanta.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/Roy-Wood-Jrs-Stand-Up-Special-FATHER-FIGURE-to-Debut-on-Comedy-Central-219-20170207 |title=Roy Wood Jr's Stand Up Special FATHER FIGURE to Debut on Comedy Central 2/19 |last=Desk |first=TV News |accessdate=February 9, 2017 |website=BroadwayWorld}}</ref> * February 21: [[Trevor Noah]]'s one-hour special ''Afraid of the Dark'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Beacon Theatre (New York City)|Beacon Theatre]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/trevor-noah-comedy-special-afraid-dark-set-netflix-968156? |title=Trevor Noah Comedy Special 'Afraid of the Dark' Set for Netflix |website=Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> * February 24: [[Nick Thune]]'s album version of his December 2016 special ''Good Guy'' is released on [[iTunes]]. The album was recorded in Portland, Oregon. * February 28: [[Mike Birbiglia]]'s one-hour special ''Thank God for Jokes'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music|BAM Harvey Theater]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/01/24/mike-birbiglia-thank-god-jokes-netflix/ |title=Mike Birbiglia's Thank God for Jokes is heading to Netflix |website=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref>
=== March ===
* March 3: [[Kurt Braunohler]]'s one-hour special ''Trust Me'' is released on [[Comedy Central]]. The special was filmed at the [[Revolution Hall]] in Portland, Oregon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://press.cc.com/press-release/2017/02/14/press-kurt-braunohler-trust-me-debuts-limited-commercial-interruption-friday-march-3-at-midnight |title=PRESS – Kurt Braunohler Trust Me Debuts Limited Commercial Interruption Friday March 3 at Midnight |website=Comedy Central Press |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ticketfly.com/event/1286547-kurt-braunohler-portland/ |title=Kurt Braunohler – Tickets – Revolution Hall – Portland, OR – September 24, 2016 |website=Ticketfly |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref> * March 3: [[Ian Harvie]]'s album version of his December 2016 special ''May the Best Cock Win'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * March 3: [[Diane Spencer]]'s one-hour special ''Seamless'' is released on [[YouTube]]. The special was filmed at The Ent Shed in Bedford.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FwmJIWxr7vY |title=Diane Spencer: Seamless (2017) |website=YouTube |accessdate=March 4, 2017}}</ref> * March 7: [[Amy Schumer]]'s one-hour special ''The Leather Special'' is released on [[Netflix]]. {{Infobox person |name = András Szántó |image = Andras Szanto in conversation with William Kentridge, Budapest Museum of Fine Arts, October 5, 2011.jpeg |image_size = |alt = |caption = Szanto in 2011 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1964|01|01}} |birth_place = Budapest |death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|1964|05|25}} --> |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = New York City |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = Columbia University, New York |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |title = |term = |predecessor = |spouse = Alanna Stang |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |website = http://www.andras-szanto.com |footnotes = }}
'''András Szántó''' (b. Jan. 1, 1964, Budapest) is a writer, researcher, and consultant in the fields of art, media, cultural policy, arts sponsorship, and philanthropy, based in New York.
==Life and work==
After a childhood and early youth spent in Budapest and London, Szántó attended the Budapest University of Economics (now [[Corvinus University]]), and, in 1988, moved to New York for graduate studies in sociology. At [[Columbia University]], as a [http://pfl-css.columbia.edu/programs/lazarsfeld-fellowship-program.html Lazarsfeld Fellow], his research interests turned to the social and commercial ramifications of the visual arts. He completed his Ph.D. dissertation in 1996 on New York art galleries and the transformation of the art world in the 1980s, working closely with [[Arthur Danto]], the Columbia philosopher and art critic.
While in graduate school, Szántó worked as a research analyst at the Media Studies Center at Columbia. In the years 1997-2005, he was deputy directory and director of the [http://www.najp.org/%20 National Arts Journalism Program] at [http://www.journalism.columbia.edu Columbia ‘s Graduate School of Journalism], in association with the [http://arts.columbia.edu School of the Arts]. In 2005-10 he directed, also at Columbia, the NEA Arts Journalism Institute in Classical Music and Opera. Other appointments have included: research affiliate of the Center for Arts and Cultural Policy Studies at [[Princeton University]], visiting critic at the [[American Academy in Rome]], and senior visiting fellow at the [http://www.artsusa.org/information_services/research/cultural_policy_listserv/default.asp%20in%20Washington,%20DC Center for Arts and Culture in Washington, DC]. He is the Moderator of the [http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-museum/press-room/news/2013/global-museum-leaders-colloquium Global Museum Leaders Colloquium] at the [http://www.metmuseum.org/ Metropolitan Museum of Art] In New York.
At Columbia, Szántó organized a [http://www.najp.org/events/conferences series of conferences] on a wide range of arts topics. Since 2008, he has moderated discussions of global museum leaders at [[Art Basel]] and [[Art Basel Miami Beach]], the [http://www.artdubai.ae/globalartforum Global Art Forum in Dubai], and other events. He was the curator of the September 2012 [http://artindustryforum.com International Art Industry Forum in Vienna], Austria. Szántó has taught courses on sociology at Columbia and [[Barnard College]], and on art business and marketing at the [http://www.sothebysinstitute.com/programmes/PNewyork.aspx Sotheby’s Institute of Art], New York. His principal professional focus is consulting and strategic advisory work with museums, foundations, cultural organizations, and corporations.
==Writing, Journalism, and Commentary==
Much of Szántó’s writing examines arts and cultural institutions, in particular the dynamics of the contemporary art world and art market. His journalism has appeared in [[The New York Times]], [[The Wall Street Journal]], [[Artforum]], [[The American Prospect]], I.D., Architecture, Print, Interiors, Men’s Vogue, [http://www.museumsassociation.org/museum-practice Museum Practice], and other publications. He is a contributing editor of [[The Art Newspaper]] and co-founder of [http://www.artworldsalon.com ArtworldSalon]. His writings and reports on the art world have explored topics ranging from the [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Will-US-museums-succeed-in-reinventing-themselves?%20/20030 strategies], [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Sixty-museums-in-search-of-a-purpose/25146 missions], and [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/The-battles-over-but-does-the-new-Barnes-work/26496 architecture] of American art museums to the role of the arts in [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Chinas-new-Age-of-Enlightenment/23495 cultural diplomacy], the [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Funding-the-state-of-the-art-/20989 rhetoric of cultural advocacy], and the transformative role of [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Time-to-lose-control/22092 technology in museums]. Earlier in his life, Szántó worked as a translator of art history and art criticism.
Szántó has also published widely on public affairs. In college, he researched the then-taboo topic of forced resettlements in Stalinist Hungary. In 1989, his undergraduate thesis became a bestselling book. In New York, he served as a correspondent for [http://magyarnarancs.hu Magyar Narancs], the first Hungarian alternative weekly, and published op-ed articles in [https://www.bostonglobe.com/ The Boston Globe] and [http://www.latimes.com/ The Los Angeles Times]. In 2007, he organized a conference, funded by Hungarian financier and philanthropist George [[George soros|Soros]], on political propaganda at the [http://www.mapdigital.com/orwell/welcome.html New York Public Library], and edited the companion book of essays, [http://www.publicaffairsbooks.com/publicaffairsbooks-cgi-bin/display?book=9781586485603 What Orwell Didn’t Know: Propaganda and the New Face of American Politics].
==Art, Business, and Strategy==
Szántó’s museum and foundation consulting involves the design and implementation of new programming and marketing initiatives, strategic planning, and the organization of conferences and public forums. He has also been retained by global corporations to design new arts engagement and sponsorship initiatives, including [https://www.artbasel.com/ Art Basel] and The Absolut Company / Pernod-Ricard, where he is the Principal Advisor to the [http://www.absolutartbureau.com/ Absolut Art Bureau]. He is the Chief Consultant of the [http://www.davidoffartinitiative.com/ Davidoff Art Initiative].
Past and present non-profit consulting clients have included The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Guggenheim Foundation, [http://asiasociety.org/ Asia Society], The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, The Pew Charitable Trusts, The National Endowment for the Arts, The Museum of Fine Arts in Budapest, The Rockefeller Archive Center, The Henry Luce Foundation, The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the RAND Corporation, the Rosenkranz Foundation, the Open Society Institute, the Aspen Institute, The Wallace Foundation, and The Robert Sterling Clark Foundation. Szántó regularly collaborates as a senior consultant with AEA Consulting, the New York arts advisory firm, where planning and evaluation clients have included The Public Art Fund, Tribeca Film Institute, The Museum of Contemporary Art in Detroit, SculptureCenter, The Meserve Kunhardt Foundation, the Roundabout Theater Company, the Knight Foundation, and the [http://www.gardnermuseum.org/ Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum].
==Cultural Policy, Diplomacy, and Philanthropy==
A former Senior Advisor to the Hungarian Minister of Culture and Education, Szántó has been active in the field of international cultural engagement. In 2001, he helped establish the Transatlantic Forum for Cultural Research at UNESCO in Paris. In 2003, he co-organized a Columbia University conference, [http://www.najp.org/publications/conferencereports/artsandminds.html Arts and Minds: Cultural Diplomacy Amid Global Tensions]. In 2012, he moderated a [http://www.salzburgglobal.org/home.html Salzburg Seminar], on Public and Private Cultural Exchange-Based Diplomacy: New Models for the 21st Century. Also in 2012, he participated in and wrote the summary report for the [http://asiasociety.org/files/pdf/USCH_MusDialogueReport.pdf Asia Society's US-China Museum Directors Forum in Beijing]. As an analyst and consultant in the field of private philanthropy, he contributed to the 2010 Aspen Institute report, [http://www.aspeninstitute.org/policy-work/nonprofit-philanthropy/Publications/The-Artist-as-Philanthropist The Artist as Philanthropist: Strengthening the Next Generation of Artist-endowed Foundations], and has served as an advisor to The Wealth & Giving Forum and the [http://www.rockarch.org Rockefeller Archive Center].
==Service and Family==
Szántó is the Chair of the Visiting Committee of the [http://www.sfai.edu San Francisco Art Institute] and has served on the advisory boards of [http://www.apexart.org Apexart], [http://www.allianceforarts.org The Alliance for the Arts], [http://www.gordonparksfoundation.org the Gordon Parks Foundation], the [http://www.scps.nyu.edu/areas-of-study/philanthropy-fundraising George H. Heyman Center for Philanthropy at NYU], and the research advisory committee of the [http://www.cpanda.org/cpanda CPANDA] (Cultural Policy and the Arts National Data Archive) at Princeton. He lives in New York City with his wife, Alanna Stang, a magazine editor and author on [http://www.papress.com/html/book.details.page.tpl?isbn=9781568989501 sustainable architecture], and their sons, Alexander and Hugo.

{{Infobox person | name = Anya Camilleri | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1972 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[British people|British]] | other_names = | education = [[University of Reading]] | occupation = Director, screenwriter | years_active = 1990–present | agent = Elizabeth Dench | known_for =Film "Jealousy" | notable_works = ''[[NY-LON]]''
''Two Golden Balls''
[[Incubus (2006 film)|''Incubus'']]
''Perfect'' }} '''Anya Joan Camilleri'''{{cite web | url=http://companycheck.co.uk/director/912372848 | title=Anya Joan Camilleri| work=Company Check | accessdate=13 April 2015}} is a British film and television director and screenwriter of Maltese descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.dencharnold.com/clients/cv.asp?client_urn=98 |title=Anya Camilleri Director |publisher=Dench Arnold |work=(Agency Resume) |accessdate=13 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923213518/http://www.dencharnold.com/clients/cv.asp?client_urn=98 |archivedate=23 September 2015 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.malta-canada.com/Hamrun/Important-people.htm | title=Profs. Mro. Charles Camilleri Composer and Conductor | work=malta-canada.com — Hamrun — Important People | accessdate=13 April 2015 | author=Scerri, John}} ==Television== After graduating from the [[University of Reading]] with a Film and Theatre degree, Camilleri's first industry job was at [[Working Title Films]], where she produced and directed commercials and pop videos, teaming up with Derek Jarman, Mike Newell, amongst others. She then directed a short film ''The Refund'' for [[BBC Television]] and a music documentary ''That Was Then, This Is Now'' (1990) for the [[BBC Two|BBC Two's]] [[DEF II]].{{cite journal | url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/95f2104abe584f9a8cdaf05a6e28241c | title=DEF II That Was Then, This Is Now | journal=Radio Times |date=April 1990 | issue=3462 | pages=35}} In 1991, she directed a drama, ''Eye Contact'' for Channel 4, starring Jason Isaacs..and in 1992/3, two episodes of ''[[Boon (TV series)|Boon]]'' and four episodes of ''[[The Bill]]'' for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0131801/ | title=Anya Camilleri | publisher=Amazon.com | work=IMDB.com | accessdate=13 April 2015 | author="Agency"}} In 1994, Camilleri directed ''Two Golden Balls'',{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MzXpbyPRVYoC&pg=PA48 | title=Beyond Representation: Television Drama and the Politics and Aesthetics of Identity | publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] | author=Harris, Geraldine | year=2006 | location=Manchester, UK | pages=48–49}} a BBC television movie starting [[Kim Cattrall]] and [[Claire Skinner]].{{cite web | url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b7db56100 | title=Two Golden Balls (1994) | publisher=British Film Institute | work=Film Forever | accessdate=8 April 2015}} Camilleri's other UK television director credits include co-creating, co-writing and lead directing 2 series of ''[[The Bill (primetime TV Series)|Liverpool 1]]'' (1998-1999) which the ITV schedule for 2 years running also two episodes of Moving On (2001).{{cite web | url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2ba9337b1e | title=Anya Camilleri | publisher=British Film Institute | work=Film Forever | accessdate=8 April 2015}} Camilleri is also the co-creator, co-writer, and a director of the television drama series ''[[NY-LON]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.screendaily.com/sharon-stone-carice-van-houten-get-satisfaction-with-media-8/5006708.article|title=Sharon Stone, Carice Van Houten get Satisfaction with Media 8|work=Screen Daily|date=13 October 2009|accessdate=5 April 2015}} The title refers to [[New York City]] and [[London]] conceived as "a single city separated by an ocean". Starring Rashida Jones and Stephen Moyet. The series ran on Britain's [[Channel 4]] from August through October 2009, and was later shown in the United States on [[BBC America]].{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Emily|title=The Rachel Miner Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h50FBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=%22Anya+Camilleri%22&source=bl&ots=ipy98rfPUv&sig=MyTccw5COFi2Jb4s4_gPRSDxv48&hl=en&sa=X&ei=T0QlVYqJO9jkoASIxoHADQ&ved=0CC4Q6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=%22Anya%20Camilleri%22&f=false|page=35}} ==Film== Camilleri directed the 2006 horror film [[Incubus (2006 film)|''Incubus'']], starring [[Tara Reid]].{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/incubus/ | title=Incubus (2005) | publisher=RottenTomatoes.com | accessdate=8 April 2015 | author=Buchanan, Jason}} In 2014, she was attached to direct ''Satisfaction'' starring [[Sharon Stone]],{{cite journal | url=https://variety.com/2009/biz/markets-festivals/stone-van-houten-find-satisfaction-1118009854/ | title=Stone, Van Houten find ‘Satisfaction’ | author=McNary, Dave | journal=Variety | date=October 12, 2009}} as a [[Cougar (slang)|"cougar"]] dating a young gigalo,{{cite news | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/sharon-stone-play-cougar-satisfaction-doesn-article-1.383627 | title=Sharon Stone will play a cougar in 'Satisfaction,' but doesn't want to be one | work=New York Daily News | date=October 12, 2009 | accessdate=8 April 2015 | location=New York, NY}} played by [[Chris Evans (actor)|Chris Evans]]{{cite news | url=http://pagesix.com/2009/11/11/chris-evans-takes-his-shirt-off-to-make-a-point/ | title=Chris Evans takes his shirt off to make a point | work=New York Post Page Six | date=November 11, 2009 | accessdate=8 April 2015 | author=Wieselman, Jarett | location=New York}} but the project has not yet filmed. Camilleri's thriller ''Perfect''{{cite web | url=http://ssa.nls.uk/film/7661 | title=Scottish Screen Archive | publisher=National Library of Scotland | accessdate=9 April 2015}} was shown at the [[Aesthetica Short Film Festival]] in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.aestheticamagazine.com/blog/asff-filmmaker-interview-anya-camilleri/|title=ASFF Filmmaker Interview: Anya Camilleri|work=Aesthetica magazine|accessdate=8 April 2015}} ==Personal life== Camilleri is married to Simon Burke, her co-creator and co-writer for ''NY-LON'', and screenwriter of Camilleri's earlier project ''Satisfaction''. ''NY-LON'' is in part based on their relationship. They have two children{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2004/aug/01/features.review27 | title=Flying to see you... | work=The Guardian | date=July 31, 2004 | accessdate=8 April 2015 | author=O'Kelly, Lisa | location=London, UK}} and a production company, Pandemonium Films Limited.{{cite web | url=http://companycheck.co.uk/company/04077159 | title=Pandemonium Films Limited | work=Company Check | date=13 November 2014 | accessdate=8 April 2015}} They live in Rome, Italy.{{cite web | url=http://www.romizivillasinumbria.com/works.html | title=Perugia, New Pool in a Villa's Garden | work=Studio Romizi — Our Renovation Works | accessdate=13 April 2015 | author1=Burke, Simon | author2= Camilleri, Anya}} Anya Camilleri is the daughter of the late Maltese composer [[Charles Camilleri]].{{cite journal | url=http://www.embassymagazine.com/court_circuit/CC_emb22_malta.html | title=Music from Malta | author=de Villiers, Pierre (photos) | journal=Embassy Magazine |date=January 2010 }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0131801}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Camilleri, Anya}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English film directors]] [[Category:English television directors]] [[Category:Women television directors]] [[Category:English women film directors]]

Television Distribution]] | channel = [[NBC]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = 7 September 1968 | last_aired =
11 January 1969 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = }} '''''Arabian Knights''''' is an [[animation|animated]] segment of ''[[The Banana Splits|The Banana Splits Adventure Hour]]'', created by [[Hanna-Barbera|Hanna-Barbera Productions]]. The series is based on the ''[[The Book of One Thousand and One Nights|Arabian Nights]]'', a classic work of Middle Eastern literature. ==Plot: Secret origins== Once a peaceful country, Persia was overrun by the powerful forces of the evil conqueror Bakaar the Black Sultan. When all the states of Persia were overthrown, Bakaar invaded the capital city of [[Baghdad]]. Bakaar and his forces breached the royal palace and forcibly claimed the throne from Prince Turhan and ordered the prince to be killed. Prince Turhan fled the palace, pursued by the guards of Bakaar. In his escape, the prince is helped by a magician named Fariik, who, with his magic, slipped away from the guards. On their way to the state of El-Rabaul to seek aid from his uncle the Caliph, Turhan and Fariik meet Raseem while being chased by the guards in the Caves of Doom. Raseem tells them that Bakaar's forces have already usurped the throne of El-Rabaul and imprisoned the Caliph and his daughter, Princess Nida. The trio then heads to El-Rabaul on Zazuum, Raheem's donkey. In El-Rabaul they rescue Princess Nida, who is about to be sold into slavery. There, Princess Nida demonstrates her mastery of disguise and voice mimicry by tricking the guards, but they soon find themselves cornered by Bakaar's men. There Bez jumps into the scene, shapeshifts into an elephant, charges through the guards, and carries everyone to safety. In the Caves of Doom, they decide to form a heroic band and swear to protect their land from the tyranny of Bakaar, thus forming an alliance called the Arabian Knights. ==Series direction== ''Arabian Knights'' was one of several animated miniseries used as filler segments for Hanna-Barbera's ''Banana Splits Adventure Hour'' show. Each episode ran between 9 and 10 minutes in length. For the most part, it competed with the other series, namely the animated ''[[The Three Musketeers (cartoon)|The Three Musketeers]]'', the part live action, part animated ''[[Micro Ventures]]'', and the live action ''[[Danger Island (TV series)|Danger Island]]'' segments. Often, the general thrust of the ''Arabian Knights'' adventures deals with the Knights trying to effect some action against Bakaar’s soldiers, finding a means to further complete their goal of turning the tables on the evil dictator, or dealing with another villain set within the Knights' universe. For the most part, these adventures were done with a semi-serious slant, with a goodly portion of action and comedy mixed in. Hardly anyone was injured or harmed—save for Bakaar's minions (with a usually comic effect), and the episodes usually had an upbeat, happy ending for the Knights. ==Characters== ===The Arabian Knights=== * '''Prince Turhan''' (voiced by [[Jay North]]) - The prince of Baghdad and rightful heir to the throne of the Sultan, Turhan is a young and handsome teenage boy. Apart from being brave and bold, he is an agile acrobat, an athlete, and a master swordsman. Turhan gathers a small group of friends to lead a revolt against the tyranny of Bakaar and reclaim his throne to restore the peace and prosperity in his state. Turhan is the ''[[de facto]]'' leader of the Knights and the driving force behind fighting Bakaar and ending the usurper’s reign. He owns a magic [[scimitar]] that can be thrown and returns like a [[boomerang]], in unique ways. * '''Princess Nida''' (voiced by [[Shari Lewis]]) - Daughter of the Caliph of El-Rabaul, Princess Nida is a lovely teenage girl who is the cousin of Prince Turhan. She is a master of disguise and an expert of voice mimicry. Nida is also skilled in martial arts and can hold her own in the Knights' battles. * '''Fariik the Magician''' (voiced by [[John Stephenson (actor)|John Stephenson]]) - A short, tubby, jolly little man, Fariik is a skilled practitioner and spell-master of the mystical arts who lends a magical hand when needed. To cast his spell, Fariik would quote "Rosan Kobar." He is the first to have offered aid to Turhan after Prince Turhan is deposed by Bakaar. Sometimes, the magic gets very difficult and can take a lot of energy out of him. Fariik can animate [[carpet]]s and pillows for the occasional airborne transport of the team. Fariik can render himself and others invisible for stealth or [[camouflage]] purposes. At times, he can dissolve himself and others into smoke to make an escape from narrow places. He can levitate objects, alter the size of things and persons, create things out of thin air, and alter the form of one thing into another. * '''Raseem the Strong''' (voiced by [[Frank Gerstle]]) - A tall muscular man with brief costume and fez, Raseem is the powerhouse of the team with incredible physical strength, endurance, and stamina. He first met Turhan and Fariik when they hid in the Caves of Doom that he occupies. Raseem mistakes them for Bakaar's men and attacks them. However, upon learning they are against Bakaar, he befriends them, and he goes with them to find the Caliph (to get his aid against Bakaar). He often boasts of his strength, saying he is as strong as 30 men. At one time, Raseem said he was as strong as seven elephants. Strong enough to shatter stone walls, lift and catch boulders, catch and throw back cannonballs, and fight off scores of Bakaar’s soldiers at a time, Raseem's power makes for a good equalizer in the Knights' battles. * '''Zazuum''' (voiced by [[Don Messick]]) - Raheem's faithful little [[donkey]] with long ears, Zazuum was first used by Turhan, Fariik, and Raheem to get to El-Rabaul. Zazuum is quite an intelligent donkey as he aids his fellow team members. Zazuum can spin himself so fast he becomes like a destructive miniature tornado that can defeat any enemy or destroy anything coming his way. He does not like his tail to be pulled, as it enrages him to the point of being a berserk loose cannon that can shatter rocks into pebbles. In addition, Zazuum can smell gold very precisely. * '''Bez The Beast''' (voiced by [[Henry Corden]]) - A dark-skinned man with a turban and green clothing, Bez can shapeshift into an animal or bird, from a mighty [[elephant]] to a tiny [[mouse]]. Often, he triggers this ability by speaking the phrase “Size of a —!” and naming the animal or bird he wishes to turn into, followed by a loud boom that proclaims his transformation. Sometimes the magical phrase is followed by clapping his hands together. If the creature is small enough, Bez can turn into multiple versions of it, such as turning into a million [[bee]]s. Bez is known to turn into some larger animals which often serve as alternate modes of transportation for the knights, like an elephant or a camel for land transportation. He can also transform into mythical creatures like a [[Pegasus|winged stallion]] or [[Roc (mythology)|roc]] for the occasional airborne transportation. His shapeshifting makes him a handy spy for the Knights in order to find out what Bakaar is planning. ===Villains=== * '''Bakaar the Black Sultan''' (voiced by [[John Stephenson (actor)|John Stephenson]]) - The corrupt conqueror and nemesis of the Arabian Knights, Bakaar usurps the throne of Turhan’s father and takes control of Baghdad. Clearly wishing to command all of the kingdoms that bow to Baghdad, he sets all of his forces to the goal of capturing Turhan (and later all of the Knights) to secure his place on the throne. While cruel, Bakaar does not usually involve himself directly in the fight against the Knights. He prefers to let his soldiers and minions to do the job. Bakaar's distinctive manner of dress—a single-spiked, fur-lined helmet in place of a crown—hints at ancestry from the [[Mongols]]. ** '''Vangore''' (voiced by [[Paul Frees]]) - Bakaar's enforcer and captain of his guards. Often hatches plots to capture the Knights. Apparently, Vangore's father was a camel driver. He has red hair shaved to a topknot (which would historically be an indication of [[Galatians (people)|Galatian]] ancestry and of being enslaved). ** '''Sundar''' - Bakaar's court magician. ==Episodes== {|class=wikitable style="width:95%; background:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#FFA500; width:20px"| Nº ! style="background:#FFA500"| Title ! style="background:#FFA500; width:130px"| Original air date {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = Joining of the Knights | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1968|9|7}} | ShortSummary = This episode tells the secret origins of Bakaar's invasion of Baghdad and how the Arabian Knights came into being. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = The Ransom | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = After saving Prince Raji ([[Dick Beals]]) from the minions of Bakaar, the Arabian Knights go to help his father the Caliph of al-ʻArish who is being held captive for ransom. Vangore takes the Caliph to Baghdad just as the Arabian Knights attack his camp. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = A Trap for Turhan | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Vangore tricks Raseem and captures him to set a trap to lure Prince Turhan and his friends to rescue Raseem and fall into Bakaar's evil scheme: a public execution of the Arabian Knights as enemies of the state. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | Title = The Great Gold Robbery | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Bakaar frames the Arabian Knights for the gold robbery from the local treasury to lure them into a deadly trap awaiting them. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | Title = The Wizard Ramnizar | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Bakaar hires an evil wizard named Ramnizar to wipe out the Arabian Knights from the face of the Earth. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = Sky Raiders of the Desert | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Nida is kidnapped by raiders on flying horses. The Arabian Knights are attacked by giant bats, but they fight them off and manage to infiltrate the Sky Raiders' fortress. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | Title = The Challenge | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = When Bez brings news of Bakaar holding a contest for the strongest man, Raseem cannot help but take the bait, getting him and Turhan captured. The Arabian Knights stealthily infiltrate the camp and deliver to Bakaar a humiliating loss. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | Title = Isle of Treachery | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Vangore captures Queen Shaheera and her son Ahmed to lure the Arabian Knights into a trap. Raseem and Bez quietly dispose of the guards to free the others and drive Vangore and his forces away from the palace. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | Title = The Sultan's Plot | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Abaddon, the Sultan of Darkness, takes away the city of Kilibad from its Caliph for denying him tribute. Abaddon then has the Arabian Knights trapped in his darkened kingdom. Using a donkey trick, the Arabian Knights cast sunlight on Abaddon's amulet, rendering his power useless. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | Title = The Reluctant Empress | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = The ruler Shiraz has the means to take Nida to make her his empress by force, but she puts up an active resistance to his seduction with a heroic spirit. The Arabian Knights follow her to the city of Abadon and battle Shiraz and his men. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | Title = The Coronation of Bakaar | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Vangore steals the crown of Araby for Bakaar. The Arabian Knights must reclaim the crown before the coronation ceremony takes place. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | Title = The Great Brass Beast | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Vangore is intent on destroying Jiwara with a brass war machine in the form of a [[war elephant]]. The war machine seems to be unstoppable for the Arabian Knights. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | Title = The Fabulous Fair | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = The Arabian Knights go undercover to Bakaar's town fair. Each event the Arabian Knights win incites more rebellious murmurings against Bakaar, especially the horse race where Zazuum poses as an Arabian zebra for a disguised Nida to ride on. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 14 | Title = The Desert Pirates | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Vangore overpowers and captures Nida and Raseem with his land pirate ship. The remaining Arabian Knights mislead Vangore to Nazir to ambush him. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 15 | Title = The Jewels of Joowar | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Vangore has ransacked Joowar and stolen its magical jewels. Turhan and Raseem are caught trying to retrieve the jewels, but the other Arabian Knights release them and proceed to fight off Vangore. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 16 | Title = The Spy | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = The Arabian Knights foil Vangore's plunder, but not without losing Zazuum to him. Bakaar's court magician Sundar impersonates Zazuum to find the Arabian Knights' hideout. Sundar's disguise does not go unnoticed and the Arabian Knights repel Bakaar's attack while Zazuum returns. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 17 | Title = The Prisoner | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = With Vangore out to kidnap Princess Tasmin, Nida takes her place, getting herself and Zazuum captured. They both escape and with the rest of the Arabian Knights, fight off Bakaar's guards and briefly take Bakaar prisoner. | LineColor = FFA500 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 18 | Title = The Royal Visitor | OriginalAirDate = | ShortSummary = Prince Kamal visits Baghdad unaware that it is under Bakaar's rule. He gets trapped in a pyramid which the abilities of Raseem and Bez have no effect on. Fariik provides the access to enter the pyramid. After going through the labyrinth and rescuing the prince, everyone escapes the place. | LineColor = FFA500 }} |} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0363312}} * [http://www.internationalhero.co.uk/a/arabnite.htm "Arabian Knights"] at International Hero * [http://www.toonopedia.com/arabiank.htm "Arabian Knights"] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. {{about|men's clothing|other uses of the word "bespoke"|Bespoke (disambiguation)}}[[File:TailoringFirstFitFront01.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Fitting of a bespoke jacket]]
'''Bespoke tailoring''' {{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-Bespoke.ogg|b|i|ˈ|s|p|oʊ|k}} is clothing made to an individual buyer's specifications by a [[tailor]].
==Clothing==
===Meaning of the term=== The word ''[[bespoke]]'' is derived from the verb "bespeak", to speak for something, in the specialised meaning "to give order for it to be made".<ref>Bailey, Nathan (1756). ''An Universal Etymological English Dictionary''. R. Ware.</ref> The term bespoke in fashion is reserved for individually patterned and crafted men's clothing, analogous to women's [[haute couture]],<ref>''Art of Textile Designing''. Global Media. {{ISBN|81-89940-03-1}}</ref> in contrast with mass-manufactured [[ready-to-wear]] (also called off-the-peg or off-the-rack). The term originated from [[Savile Row]], a street in London considered the "Golden Mile of tailoring".<ref name=Norton>{{cite web|last=Norton|first=Kate|title=Savile Row Never Goes Out of Style|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2006-10-31/savile-row-never-goes-out-of-stylebusinessweek-business-news-stock-market-and-financial-advice|work=Bloomberg Businessweek|accessdate=14 December 2013|date=31 October 2006}}</ref>
Bespoke clothing is traditionally cut from a pattern drafted from scratch for the customer, and so differs from [[ready-to-wear]], which is factory made in finished condition and standardised sizes, and from [[made to measure]], which is produced to order from an adjusted block pattern. The opposition of terms did not initially imply that a bespoke garment was necessarily well built, but since the development of ready-to-wear in the beginning of the twentieth century,<ref>Ugolini, Laura (2003). ''Men and Menswear: Sartorial Consumption in Britain 1880–1939'', p. 181. Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. {{ISBN|0-7546-0384-9}}</ref> bespoke clothing is now more expensive and is generally accompanied by a high quality of construction.<ref group="n">In article published in ''[[Textile History]]'' (Volume 34, Number 2, November 2003 , pp. 192–213. ''Ready-to-wear or Made-to-measure? Consumer Choice in the British Menswear Trade'') Laura Ugolini concluded that "interested and well-informed male consumers generally preferred to buy bespoke suits: while usually more expensive than their ready-made counterparts, these were also perceived to be better quality, better looking, and better value, and therefore most likely to enhance the wearer's sense of self-worth as a manly, discerning and successful consumer".</ref>
While the distinction conferred by haute couture is protected by law in France,<ref group="n">A certain number of formal criteria, including the design for private customers with one or more fittings, must be met for a fashion house to use the label and a list of eligible houses is made official every year by the French Ministry of Industry.</ref> the British [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]] has ruled it is a fair practice to use the term "bespoke" for products that do not fully incorporate traditional construction methods.<ref name="Cockroft">{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2149810/Savile-Row-tailors-lose-fight-to-preserve-the-term-bespoke.html |first=Lucy| last=Cockroft| title=Savile Row tailors lose fight to preserve the term bespoke|work = The Telegraph |date=2008-06-19 |accessdate=2008-10-10}}</ref> The [[Savile Row Bespoke Association]], a trade group of traditional tailors, disagrees.<ref group="n">The tailor Richard Anderson wrote an article in the Telegraph to explain that "the ASA has got the ruling wrong" ({{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/2151888/Savile-Row-tailor-Richard-Anderson-bespoke-must-mean-bespoke.html|title=Savile Row tailor Richard Anderson: bespoke must mean bespoke |accessdate=2008-10-10|first=Richard|last=Anderson|date=2008-06-18|work=The Telegraph}}).</ref><ref name="Sim">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/0ea5cbf6-4eed-11dd-ba7c-000077b07658.html|title=The b-word: not cut and dried|accessdate=2008-10-10 |first=Josh|last=Sim|date=2008-07-12|work=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref>
===Compared to made-to-measure=== Between the extremes of bespoke and ready-to-wear, there has existed since the end of the 19th century<ref group="n">In 1895, the [[Leeds]] Factory Clothing Co. veered between calling itself "manufacturing clothiers" and "bespoke tailors" (''cf.'' {{cite book |author = Benson, John |year = 2003 |title = A Nation of Shopkeepers: Five Centuries of British Retailing |publisher = Houghton Mifflin Cookbooks |isbn = 1-86064-708-1 |page = 102 }}).</ref> a "grey area of garments for which the customer was measured, but that were then made up to the closest standard size, often, but by no means always, in a factory."<ref>Benson, John (2003). ''A Nation of Shopkeepers: Five Centuries of British Retailing'', p.102. I.B.Tauris. {{ISBN|1-86064-708-1}}</ref> The distinction made here is between bespoke, created without use of a pre-existing pattern, and [[made to measure]], which alters a standard-sized pattern to fit the customer.<ref name="Norton"/> Technological change makes this distinction more subtle, since fittings are increasingly required for made-to-measure. A bespoke service may require an individually-cut pattern, which is then kept should further suits be required; made-to-measure measurements are often stored on a computer. Even hand-work, often cited as a benchmark of bespoke, is now increasingly found in made-to-measure garments, while machine-making plays some part in the creation of most bespoke suits. With a bespoke suit, a pattern is designed and made from scratch based on the client's measurements, often from 20+ measurements involving multiple fittings, and takes considerably longer to produce than a made-to-measure garment.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sharpsense.ca/blogs/style-guide/made-to-measure-vs-bespoke-vs-off-the-rack |title=Made to Measure vs Bespoke vs Off the Rack |publisher=sharpsense.ca |accessdate=2017-09-26 }}</ref> This ensures a precise fit, particularly in the shoulders as well as the posture areas. This [[custom-fit|custom fit]] is handy for clients with short or long necks, high or low shoulders, excess girth, high hips, large or flat seats, and more. Made-to-measure cannot adjust for these shapes and slopes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://joeydimz.com/bespoke |title=Bespoke |publisher=joeydimz.com |accessdate=2017-09-26 }}</ref>
In addition, new technologies have allowed for bespoke garments to be made with [[lean manufacturing]] practices and digital patterning, making new patterns within minutes and fully bespoke garments in hours, at a price point similar to made to measure or even [[mass production]].
===Advertising Standards Authority ruling=== In June 2008, the [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]] (ASA), a British advertising regulator, ruled that an advertisement describing a suit "put into a 'working-frame' where it would be cut and sewn by machine"<ref name="Asa">{{cite web |url=http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/adjudications/Public/TF_ADJ_44555.htm |title=Sartoriani London |accessdate=2008-10-09 |work=ASA Adjudications |author=Advertising Standards Authority |date=2008-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122150946/http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/adjudications/Public/TF_ADJ_44555.htm |archivedate=2008-11-22 |df= }} </ref> as a "bespoke suit uniquely made according to your personal measurements & specification"<ref name="Asa"/> was not breaching the Authority's self-proclaimed advertising codes,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/about/ |title=About the Advertising Standards Authority |author=Advertising Standards Authority |accessdate=2008-10-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015205424/http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/about/ |archivedate=2008-10-15 |df= }}</ref> notably the truthfulness rule,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/codes/cap_code/ShowCode.htm?clause_id=1502 |title=The CAP Code: truthfulness rule |author=Advertising Standards Authority |accessdate=2008-10-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915153343/http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/codes/cap_code/ShowCode.htm?clause_id=1502 |archivedate=2008-09-15 |df= }}</ref> because the use of the term bespoke was not deemed likely to confuse. The ruling was significant in formalising a less traditional definition of bespoke clothing, even though the older distinction with made-to-measure was recognised.
The ruling cited the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' definition of bespoke as "made to order", and considered that despite the fact a bespoke suit was "fully hand-made and the pattern cut from scratch, with an intermediary baste stage which involved a first fitting so that adjustments could be made to a half-made suit",<ref name="Asa"/> while a suit made-to-measure "would be cut, usually by machine, from an existing pattern, and adjusted according to the customer's measurements",<ref name="Asa"/> "both fully bespoke and made-to-measure suits were "made to order" in that they were made to the customer's precise measurements and specifications, unlike off-the-peg suits".<ref name="Asa"/>
Some, such as the etymologist [[Michael Quinion]], considered the ruling showed that "the historic term of art had moved on".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldwidewords.org/qa/qa-bes4.htm |title= Bespoke|accessdate=2008-10-09 |first=Michael |last=Quinion |date= 2008-09-13| work=World Wide Words}}</ref> Some others concluded that "bespoke tailoring has traditionally, if unofficially, meant something more than the dictionary definition allows"<ref name="Sim"/> and that the ASA "took a rather ignorant decision to declare that there is no difference between bespoke and made-to-measure."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mensflair.com/news/a-loss-to-sartorial-language.php |title=A loss to (sartorial) language |accessdate=2008-10-10 |first=Simon |last=Crompton |date=2008-07-01 |work=Men's Flair |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021143340/http://www.mensflair.com/news/a-loss-to-sartorial-language.php |archivedate=2008-10-21 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Mass customization]] * [[New bespoke movement]] * [[Hong Kong Tailors]]
